The Certified Social Engineering Prevention Specialist (CSEPS) was the worldâ€™s first professional certification focused specifically on defending against social engineering attacks [?].
data.background#Background: Co-created by Alex Kasper and Kevin Mitnick in the early 2000s, CSEPS emerged from their combined decades of experienceâ€”Mitnickâ€™s infamous exploits demonstrating social engineeringâ€™s power, and their joint work developing defensive countermeasures.
data.legacy#Legacy: The concepts pioneered in CSEPS have since become standard in security awareness training industry-wide. The emphasis on â€œmanufactured urgencyâ€ as a key manipulation techniqueâ€”now central to Alexâ€™s current workâ€”originated in this early curriculum.
data.related#Related: [Citation not found: art-of-deception] - Kevin Mitnickâ€™s book expanding on many CSEPS concepts [Citation not found: freedom-downtime-2001] - Documentary featuring both Mitnick and Kasper
data.the-approach#The Approach:
CSEPS training covered:
Recognition - Identifying social engineering attempts across phone, email, and in-person vectors Psychological principles - Understanding why social engineering works (authority, urgency, reciprocity, etc.) Organizational defenses - Policies, procedures, and culture changes that reduce vulnerability Incident response - What to do when an attempt is detected
data.the-problem-cseps-addressed#The Problem:
At the time, cybersecurity certifications focused almost exclusively on technical controls: firewalls, encryption, network security. But as Mitnick had demonstrated repeatedly, the weakest link in any security system is the human element.
Social engineeringâ€”manipulating people into revealing information or taking actions that compromise securityâ€”was (and remains) the most effective attack vector. Yet no formal training or certification existed to help organizations defend against it.

data: Naturesign is a B2B SaaS platform that automates the generation of regulatory documents for the flavor and fragrance industry.
data.current-status#Current Status: Naturesign currently serves clients in the F&F industry and is actively expanding. For more information, visit naturesign.com or contact info@naturesign.com.
data.technology#Technology: Built on Salesforce with custom Lightning Web Components, Naturesign leverages Alexâ€™s deep Salesforce expertise to deliver a robust, scalable solution.
data.the-problem#The Problem:
Companies in the flavor and fragrance industry must produce extensive regulatory documentation for every productâ€”safety data sheets, compliance certificates, ingredient declarations, and more. This documentation is:
Time-consuming to create manually Error-prone when done by hand Required by multiple regulatory bodies worldwide Constantly needing updates as regulations change
data.the-solution#The Solution:
Naturesign automates this entire workflow:
Data Input - Product formulations and ingredient data are entered once Document Generation - The platform automatically produces all required regulatory documents Compliance Updates - As regulations change, documents can be regenerated automatically Multi-format Output - Documents are produced in formats required by different regulatory bodies

data: Return Fire was a vehicular combat strategy game produced by Alex Kasper at Silent Software for the 3DO Interactive Multiplayer in 1995 [?].
data.legacy#Legacy: Return Fire demonstrated Alexâ€™s early career in interactive entertainment before his pivot to cybersecurity work. The game remains a cult classic among 3DO enthusiasts and is frequently cited in discussions of the consoleâ€™s best titles.
data.notable-features#Notable Features: Classical music soundtrack (including Ride of the Valkyries, which became iconic to the game) Split-screen multiplayer Destructible environments Multiple vehicle types with distinct capabilities
data.overview#Overview: Return Fire combined action gameplay with strategic elements, allowing players to choose between different military vehicles (jeep, tank, helicopter, armored support vehicle) to capture the enemyâ€™s flag while defending their own base.
data.reception#Reception:
